image.altText: A group of people, fronted by a man talking and pointing upwards, outside the High Court.

items.synopsis: Qantas took a long-running battle with the Transport Workers' Union over sacked staff to the High Court, where the airline today lost its appeal.

title.children: Qantas workers celebrate historic 'The Castle vibes' win after High Court ruled the airline illegally sacked staff

image.altText: Smoke coming out of a car after it was caught on fire

items.synopsis: Police say a man shot in a car park in Campsie overnight is known to authorities, as they search for the assailants.

title.children: 'Lucky to be alive': Police hunt for gunmen after man shot in head and chest in south-west Sydney

image.altText: A young boy, crying, sits on a rock.

items.synopsis: Last week's earthquake destroyed every building in the remote village of Tikekht. Now anger is building as recovery efforts stall and newly orphaned children pick through the rubble with nowhere else to go.

title.children: The Moroccan town wiped off the map in one day

image.altText: A man with short dark hair pictured with his daughter whose face is pixellated

items.synopsis: The family of Terry Czernowski, the man fatally shot at his Kellerberrin workplace last week, breaks its silence to pass on their thanks to WA Police for their handling of the tragic incident.

title.children: 'Horrible tragedy': Family of WA man fatally shot at work in Kellerberrin breaks silence to thank community

image.altText: An aerial view of Sydney Harbour and the Harbour Bridge, amid smoke haze.

items.synopsis: Sydney is the most recent city to be covered in an an eerie smoke haze, a familiar sight to Australians during autumn and spring as fire crews make hazard reduction burns ahead of summer.

title.children: Sydney has been trapped under a blanket of smoke for days. Here's why

image.altText: A side shot of a man's face and neck.

items.synopsis: A parliamentary probe investigating links between former cabinet minister Stuart Robert and a Canberra lobbying firm, and the subsequent awarding of government contracts calls on the National Anti-Corruption Commission to investigate the saga.

title.children: Former cabinet minister Stuart Robert referred to national corruption body

image.altText: Serhii Bolvinov working

items.synopsis: When Russian forces stormed Izium last year, the Ukrainian city was a hub for torture. One year later, the painstaking work to identify those responsible continues, with a little help from social media.

title.children: Torturers fled the Ukrainian city of Izium a year ago — they left clues about their identity online

image.altText: Photo of sitting stationary on the Sydney airport runway.

items.synopsis: The local share market is trading lower today, following Wall Street's losses. Qantas loses its High Court appeal over the sacking of 1,700 workers during the pandemic. Follow updates in our live blog.

title.children: Qantas issues first-ever apology to workers it illegally sacked during pandemic, ASX in the red led by tech stocks

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Australians are spending (slightly more) again, particularly on education, transport and recreation. The CommBank Household Spending Insights index rose 0.7% in August from July, which was flat. The index is based on 12 spending categories and uses payment data from about 7 million Commonwealth Bank customers (which comprises about 30% of Australian consumer transactions). A increase in the number of international students meant spending on education grew 2.8%, while the FIFA Women's World Cup and big-name concert tours pushed recreational spending up 1.9%. Higher petrol prices drove up spending on transport by about 2%. However, the annual rate of increases is significantly down from its peak of 18% last yea r. CBA Chief Economist Stephen Halmarick says annual spending growth remains subdued as households manage the increased cost of living. "The effects of the 400bp of Reserve Bank of Australia interest rate rises is clearly reflected in a significant slowdown in annual household spending growth measured by the CommBank HSI Index. Monetary policy is now restrictive and financial conditions will continue to tighten in the months ahead on the lagged effect of RBA interest rate hikes and the fixed rate mortgage refinancing task. We continue to expect household spending to weaken further over the remainder of 2023 and into 2024." Households spent less on hospitality and utilities (reflecting the government rebates available for energy bills).
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Household spending rebounds helped by FIFA Women's World Cup

children.content: Australians are spending (slightly more) again, particularly on education, transport and recreation.
The CommBank Household Spending Insights
index rose 0.7%
in August from July, which was flat.
The index is based on 12 spending categories and uses payment data from about 7 million Commonwealth Bank customers (which comprises about 30% of Australian consumer transactions).
A increase in the number of international students meant spending on
education grew 2.8%
, while the FIFA Women's World Cup and big-name concert tours pushed
recreational spending up 1.9%
. Higher petrol prices drove up spending on
transport by about 2%
However, the
annual rate of increases is significantly down from its peak of 18% last yea
r.
CBA Chief Economist Stephen Halmarick says annual spending growth remains subdued as households manage the increased cost of living.
"The effects of the 400bp of Reserve Bank of Australia interest rate rises is clearly reflected in a significant slowdown in annual household spending growth measured by the CommBank HSI Index.
Monetary policy is now restrictive and financial conditions will continue to tighten in the months ahead on the lagged effect of RBA interest rate hikes and the fixed rate mortgage refinancing task.
We continue to expect household spending to weaken further over the remainder of 2023 and into 2024."
Households spent less on hospitality and utilities (reflecting the government rebates available for energy bills).

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Well, getting an accurate read on what's happening with Qantas shares is proving difficult! After small gains in morning trade, Qantas shares were down 0.6% after lunch, and just in the last few minutes they're slowly creeping up about 0.2% to $5.59 (at 2.40pm AEST). We're interested in following the airline's share price today because of the landmark High Court decision this morning, that found Qantas illegally sacked 1,700 employees during COVID-19. All this has made me curious to check what's been happening with the Qantas share price during 2023. Turns out shares are down 18 per cent from the airline's peak price in March (at $6.80). Let's have a look in chart form:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: An update on Qantas shares

after lunch, and just in the last few minutes they're slowly creeping up about
We're interested in following the airline's share price today because of the landmark High Court decision this morning, that found Qantas illegally sacked 1,700 employees during COVID-19.
All this has made me curious to check what's been happening with the Qantas share price during 2023.
Turns out shares are down 18 per cent from the airline's peak price in March (at $6.80).
Let's have a look in chart form:

props.alt: A chart showing the ups and downs of Qantas' share price in 2023

(Eikon)

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The federal government has introduced legislation today that will ban the use of credit cards for online gambling. The ban will also cover the use of cryptocurrency and digital currencies. The Minister for Social Services Amanda Rishworth says it will protect vulnerable Australians. "You can't use your credit card to place a bet for land-based gambling and the same rules should apply for online gambling too." Companies could face fines of up to $235,000 if they don't enforce the new rules. Financial Counselling Australia's (FCA) director of policy and campaigns Lauren Levin says it's a major win in the battle to reduce gambling harm. "Digital currencies can have wild fluctuations in value, so not only do people speculate on their bets, but also on the movement in the digital currency." However, the FCA is disappointed online lotteries won't be included in the ban. "Online lotteries have changed the whole situation, as the danger of losing large sums is now just as high as someone gambling on online sports betting. "There is no good reason for online lotteries to allow people to buy a $10,000 ticket on credit, or for people to enter a $3,000 syndicate on credit. "Gambling is gambling."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: You soon won't be able to gamble online using credit cards

children.content: The federal government has introduced legislation today that will
ban the use of credit cards for online gambling
The ban will also cover the use of cryptocurrency and digital currencies.
The Minister for Social Services Amanda Rishworth says it will protect vulnerable Australians.
"You can't use your credit card to place a bet for land-based gambling and the same rules should apply for online gambling too."
Companies could face
fines of up to $235,000
if they don't enforce the new rules.
Financial Counselling Australia's (FCA) director of policy and campaigns Lauren Levin says
it's a major win in the battle to reduce gambling harm
"Digital currencies can have wild fluctuations in value, so not only do people speculate on their bets, but also on the movement in the digital currency."
However, the FCA is
disappointed online lotteries won't be included in the ban
"Online lotteries have changed the whole situation, as the danger of losing large sums is now just as high as someone gambling on online sports betting.
"There is no good reason for online lotteries to allow people to buy a $10,000 ticket on credit, or for people to enter a $3,000 syndicate on credit.
"Gambling is gambling."

items.synopsis: The Mediterranean storm has claimed thousands of lives and left vast areas of Libya underwater. Here's what we know about why it was so powerful, and the extent of the devastation.

title.children: Thousands of people are feared dead in Libya. Why was Storm Daniel so deadly?

items.synopsis: I’m not sure whether I’ve got any unclaimed Qantas flight credits. I haven’t looked, which is exactly what Qantas wants. Separating people determined to get their money from those who give up is a standard business practice, writes Peter Martin

title.children: Making refunds hard is standard practice — but Qantas appears to have added a twist

image.altText: Two young women stand outdoors in a composite photo.
